author: Daniel Palmer
title: Scoreboard: Car trouble
text:
A lack of data has been a regular foundation for a positive session of late, but not so last night as commodities and stocks were sold off with venom despite the dearth of economic reports.
Carmakers and miners bore the brunt of the pain on stock exchanges, with the latter plagued by concerns around the Chinese economy ahead of crucial manufacturing data due out today.
Indeed, it appeared investors were launching a pre-emptive strike on the expectation manufacturing numbers will again disappoint.
Copper was among the hardest hit, surrendering 3.6 per cent, while zinc hit a new six-year low and US oil gave back almost 2 per cent.
Sentiment was also dampened by the Asian Development Bank’s decision to lower its China growth forecast from 7.2 per cent to 6.8 per cent on Tuesday.
Meanwhile, carmakers were caught in the backlash of the emissions data scandal engulfing German giant Volkswagen .
VW’s executives took a contrite tone in response to explosive revelations 11 million of its diesel cars had been equipped with devices that could skew emissions data. Its shares were pummelled a further 20 per cent amid news of a profit downgrade and a decision to set aside over $10 billion to cover potential fines and legal fees.
European peers BMW , Daimler , Fiat Chrysler , Peugeot and Renault all plunged between 6 and 9 per cent as investor confidence in the industry was compromised.
The developments helped drive Germany’s DAX 30 down 3.8 per cent, while France’s CAC 40 tumbled 3.4 per cent, Italy’s Milan Stock Exchange dived 3.3 per cent and the UK’s FTSE 100 slid 2.8 per cent.
BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto tanked 5.1 per cent and 3.5 per cent in London trade, respectively. The session was so dire, however, that these numbers were above par compared to their main rivals, with troubled Glencore setting the low mark thanks to a drop of more than 10 per cent.
The Athens Stock Exchange extended its lacklustre response to the latest Greek election, slipping 2.3 per cent.
On Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrial Average weakened 1.1 per cent, the S&P 500 slid 1.2 per cent and the Nasdaq Composite Index backtracked 1.5 per cent. Key indexes were pointing down more than 1.5 per cent for much of the session before staging a minor rally near the close.
The Richmond Fed index weakened into negative territory, hitting a mark of -5 in September and falling short of expectations of a -2 reading. The number is the latest sign of softness in the US manufacturing sector, but does little to temper a positive view on the broader US economy.
In other market action:
-- The Australian dollar slumped as commodities hit the skids. At 6am (AEST), the local unit is trading at US70.85c, down from US71.52c on Tuesday. It fell as low as US70.56c during the session.
-- US Nymex crude yielded 1.8 per cent to $US45.83 as investors again turned cautious on demand prospects. Global benchmark Brent crude bucked the trend in inching up 0.3 per cent to $US49.08.
-- Gold dipped 0.7 per cent to $US1,124.80 an ounce as the US dollar gained ground.
-- Iron ore held steady at $US57.10 a tonne for a second straight day.
-- ASX futures are pointing down 62 points, or 1.2 per cent, as of 6.15am (AEST).
Ahead: Manufacturing data will drive markets, with monthly readings on tap in China, Europe and the US over the next 24 hours.
